metadata.title: California Landscape Plants Encyclopedia
metadata.source: YouTube transcripts from John Valentino / John and Bob's Corporation
metadata.note: All plant names decoded from speech-to-text transcription artifacts and verified with correct botanical nomenclature.
metadata.description: Comprehensive plant encyclopedia extracted from landscape design YouTube channel transcripts. All plant names have been decoded from speech-to-text transcription artifacts and verified with correct botanical nomenclature.

plants.description: Featured extensively as a signature ornamental tree for California gardens. Multiple varieties discussed including upright and weeping forms. Used in shade gardens, courtyards, and as focal points. Requires regular pruning every 6 months to maintain shape. Prefers afternoon shade in hot Central Valley climates.
Weeping, lacy-leafed form of Japanese maple. Used as specimen tree in shade gardens and courtyards. Signature plant in the designer's own garden. Requires careful pruning to maintain cascading form.
Red weeping laceleaf Japanese maple variety. Deep burgundy-red foliage. Popular cultivar for small gardens and containers.
Green laceleaf weeping Japanese maple. Provides contrasting green laceleaf form when paired with red varieties.
Compact dwarf Japanese maple with deep red foliage. Grows very slowly, suitable for small spaces and containers.
Upright Japanese maple with brilliant red foliage. Better heat tolerance than many Japanese maple varieties.
Upright Japanese maple variety discussed for garden use in Central Valley landscapes.
Unique Japanese maple cultivar with distinctive star-shaped leaves. Collector variety.
Japanese maple cultivar discussed in the maple garden tour. Known for interesting leaf form and fall color.
Japanese maple variety with striking coral-red bark in winter. Provides year-round interest. Green leaves turn golden yellow in fall.
Dwarf form of ginkgo tree suitable for small gardens. Unique butterfly-shaped leaves. Slow-growing, low-maintenance ornamental tree.

One of the best fall color trees for the Central Valley. Keith Davey is the grafted variety that guarantees spectacular fall color. Well-behaved roots. Used extensively in California landscapes. Large tree, potentially too big for small sites.
Common shade tree in California. Mentioned as a park-scale tree that can be too large for small residential sites. Fast growing and generally low maintenance.
Small patio-scale tree with spring flowers. Multiple varieties available. Appropriate for small gardens where large trees would be too big. Used in courtyard plantings and no-lawn front yard designs.
California native small tree with magenta spring flowers. Drought tolerant once established. Appropriate for small garden spaces.
Ornamental redbud cultivar with colorful multi-hued foliage emerging in shades of red, orange, and gold.
Redbud variety with spectacular orange to gold emerging foliage. Small ornamental tree for focal points.
Redbud variety seen at nursery tour. Noted for thick, glossy, leathery leaves and deep magenta flowers. More heat-tolerant than Eastern Redbud.

Major flowering tree for California summer landscapes. Multiple varieties discussed including Tuscarora (coral-pink), Muskogee (lavender), Black Diamond (dark foliage), and Natchez (white, multi-trunk). Used lining walkways and as specimen trees.
White-flowering crape myrtle variety. Used as multi-trunk specimens in the front garden remodel. Beautiful cinnamon-brown exfoliating bark.
Large evergreen shade tree. Described as a park tree that is too big for small residential sites. Common in older California neighborhoods.
Mentioned as a common California street/shade tree. Can develop problems in landscapes.

plants.transcript_spelling: smoked Bush, smoke bush, Smoke Tree
plants.description: Ornamental small tree/large shrub with fluffy smoke-like flower clusters. Dwarf form used in courtyard plantings. Provides purple or green foliage interest.
Large deciduous tree with graceful weeping habit. Requires significant water and space.
Large native California shade tree with distinctive mottled bark. Commonly used in parks and large landscapes.
Ornamental tree with white bark. Can struggle in Central Valley heat.
Heat-tolerant birch variety. Better suited to hot Central Valley conditions than European White Birch. Exfoliating salmon-colored bark.
Ornamental tree with showy red flower candles in spring. Seen on spring garden tour. Hybrid of horse chestnut and red buckeye.
Common ornamental tree in California landscapes. Purple foliage with pink spring flowers. Seen in spring garden tour.
Ornamental spring-flowering tree. Noted in spring garden tour. Pink or white blossoms.
Large deciduous shade tree with distinctive tulip-shaped leaves and flowers. One of the tallest eastern North American hardwoods. Can be very large for residential sites.
Large deciduous shade tree known for star-shaped leaves and excellent fall color. Produces spiny seed balls. Common in California landscapes.
Hybrid maple seen at nursery tour. Cross between red maple and silver maple. Selected for reliable fall color in warmer climates.
Ornamental pear tree mentioned in context of lawn problems. Known to be short-lived and prone to splitting. Increasingly avoided in modern landscapes.
Eastern North American native flowering tree. Spring-blooming with pink bracts. Seen in spring garden tour.
Asian dogwood species used in zoo Asian exhibit landscaping. Later-blooming than Cornus florida. More disease-resistant. Distinctive pointed bracts.
Cornus kousa cultivar seen at nursery tour. Large white bracts. Good disease resistance.
Deciduous tree mentioned in landscaping context. Can be invasive in some regions. Provides fall color.
Fast-growing deciduous tree. Mentioned in general landscape discussions.
Deciduous flowering shrub/small tree. Summer-blooming with large tropical-looking flowers.

Signature Mediterranean tree for California landscapes. Multi-trunk form used extensively. Low water, low maintenance. Used as small patio trees in front gardens. Four used in the designer's own low-maintenance garden.
Large evergreen tree with glossy leaves and fragrant white flowers. A classic Southern tree also used in California.
Deciduous magnolia hybrid with deep burgundy-purple tulip-shaped flowers. Seen on spring garden tour. Striking specimen tree.
Large evergreen oak. Used in front garden remodel for permanent shade structure.
Mediterranean evergreen oak with thick corky bark. Drought tolerant and well-adapted to California's climate.
Mentioned in the 15 biggest trees video. Large deciduous oak native to eastern North America. Among the largest oak species.
Multiple oak species discussed as large shade trees. Generally too big for small residential sites. Common in California landscapes.

California's state tree. Massive evergreen conifer. Multiple specimens discussed in various garden settings. Needs adequate water. Japanese maples and redwoods pair well together. Featured in the 15 biggest trees discussion.
The biggest tree by volume in the world. Native to the Sierra Nevada of California. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.

plants.transcript_spelling: Dodar cedar, drr Cedar, arodor Cedar
plants.description: Large graceful evergreen conifer. Used as a specimen tree in larger landscapes. Mentioned dropping a branch on a car.
Large pine tree used in California landscapes. Distinctive long needles.
Various pine species mentioned in landscape context.
One of the tallest tree species. Discussed in 15 biggest trees video and as a material for fencing and arbors.
Versatile evergreen used as screen, hedge, or small tree. Dense foliage. Good for privacy screening in California gardens.
Versatile evergreen shrub/tree used for screening and hedging. Can be pruned into tree form. Glossy foliage.
Hybrid strawberry tree seen at nursery tour. Evergreen with attractive cinnamon bark, pink flowers, and red-orange fruit. Excellent multi-trunk small tree for California.
Thornless palo verde hybrid. Green-barked desert tree with yellow spring flowers. Seen at nursery tour and used in restaurant landscaping. Drought tolerant.
Narrow columnar evergreen conifer. Used as a screening element on the opposite side of driveways. Very narrow footprint. Low maintenance.

plants.transcript_spelling: Saratoga, bay called Saratoga, Sweet Bay Little Ragu
plants.description: Bay laurel variety used throughout the designer's low-maintenance garden as the consistent tree element. Also discussed dwarf bay 'Little Ragu' for smaller spaces. Aromatic evergreen.
Large evergreen shrub/tree used for screening and hedging. New growth emerges bright red. Fast growing.
Large-growing Indian hawthorn that can be trained as a small tree. Pink flowers. Evergreen.
Dwarf form of Indian hawthorn. Compact evergreen shrub for borders and low hedges.
Ancient deciduous tree with fan-shaped leaves and brilliant yellow fall color. Male trees preferred (no smelly fruit).
Tallest flowering plant in the world. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video. Native to southeastern Australia.
Tropical eucalyptus with spectacularly colorful peeling bark in shades of green, blue, orange, and maroon. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.
Large eucalyptus species. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video. Common in California but can be problematic due to size and fire risk.
Graceful weeping cypress from the Himalayas. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.
Tallest known non-redwood tree in the world. Southeast Asian tropical species. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.
Ancient New Zealand conifer. One of the world's largest tree species. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.
Massive tropical tree with buttress roots. One of the largest trees in the Americas. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.
The oldest living trees on Earth, some over 4,000 years old. Native to high elevations in the western United States. Discussed in the 15 biggest trees video.
Classic formal hedge plant. Dense evergreen. Used for borders and formal garden structure.
Common hedge plant. Texas Privet mentioned specifically for no-lawn front yard designs. Dense growth for screening.

Versatile evergreen shrub with bamboo-like foliage. Multiple varieties used: 'Flirt' and 'Blush Pink' (dwarf, colorful), standard domestica, and special dwarf forms. Used in courtyard plantings and no-lawn designs.

plants.transcript_spelling: Little John bottlebrush, Little John bottle brush
plants.description: Dwarf bottlebrush shrub used as an informal hedge. Red brush-like flowers attract hummingbirds. Used in the designer's low-maintenance garden. Needs occasional pruning to maintain height.
Dwarf fruitless olive shrub. Used for screening walls. Dense compact growth. Very drought tolerant.
Sprawling evergreen shrub with sky-blue flowers. Blooms prolifically in California. Used in drought-tolerant landscapes and front garden remodels.
Large flowering shrub that attracts butterflies. A riot of color when blooming. Used in front garden remodels and landscape plantings.

plants.transcript_spelling: fola cellana, pineapple guava, Feijoa sellowiana
plants.description: Dual-purpose shrub/small tree with edible fruit and ornamental flowers. Named varieties recommended for better fruit. Can be used as a hedge, screen, or specimen. Very well-adapted to California.
Fall/winter-blooming camellia with white semi-double flowers. Excellent for shade gardens and screening.
Rare yellow-flowering camellia hybrid. Seen on spring garden tour. Collector's plant.
Evergreen shrub with extremely fragrant small white flowers. Excellent for hedges and screening. Fragrance carries throughout the garden.

plants.transcript_spelling: lur petalum, lur pedms, lorii corop, Loropetalum
plants.description: Versatile evergreen shrub with purple foliage and pink fringe-like flowers. 'Jazz Hands Variegated' cultivar noted on spring tour. Also used as ground cover form. Multiple sizes available.
Bold-textured shade plant with large palmate leaves. 'Spider Web' variegated cultivar also mentioned. Excellent for shade gardens.
Tropical-looking evergreen shrub with finely divided foliage. Used in sheltered garden areas.
Dense evergreen screening shrub/tree. Used to create garden room boundaries in the low-maintenance garden. Dark glossy foliage.
Dense evergreen used for screening and hedging. Mentioned in no-lawn front yard and restaurant landscaping. Fast growing.

plants.transcript_spelling: Mahonia soft Caress, Mahonia Soft Caress
plants.description: Compact mahonia with soft, non-spiny foliage. Used in zoo Asian exhibit landscaping. Yellow flowers, shade tolerant.
Compact evergreen viburnum with clusters of white-pink flowers. Good for hedging and foundation plantings.
Japanese holly with small fine-textured leaves. Used for hedging and topiary.
Very narrow columnar Japanese holly. Excellent for tight vertical accent without taking much horizontal space.
Various holly species mentioned for hedging and screening in California gardens.
Mediterranean shrub thriving in clay soil. Drought tolerant, paper-like flowers in white or pink. Well-adapted to California's climate.
Large deciduous shrub/small tree with lavender-blue flower spikes in summer. Excellent for clay soil. Attracts butterflies.
Deciduous shrub with intensely fragrant white flowers in spring. Old-fashioned garden favorite.
Compact form of oleander with pink flowers. Very heat and drought tolerant. All parts toxic. Good for hot, dry areas.
Tropical-looking evergreen shrub with large colorful flowers. Popular in California landscapes.
Compact burgundy-leafed shrub. Used for color contrast in garden beds. Deciduous in some climates.
Compact deciduous flowering shrub with flat-topped pink flower clusters. Low maintenance.
California native shrub with bright yellow flowers. Drought tolerant. Grows well in poor soils.
Acid-loving shrub with showy flower clusters. Seen on spring garden tour. Requires afternoon shade and acidic soil in California.
Evergreen shrub with intensely fragrant white flowers. Requires acidic soil and consistent moisture.
Popular flowering shrub with large rounded flower clusters. Blue or pink depending on soil pH. Used in shade garden plantings. Needs regular water.
Native hydrangea with oak-shaped leaves and cone-shaped white flower clusters. Excellent fall color. Used in no-lawn front yard design. More drought tolerant than mophead hydrangeas.
Edible fruiting shrub. Requires acidic soil and consistent moisture. Mentioned for edible landscape use.
Deciduous fruit tree/large shrub. Very well-adapted to hot California valleys. Used in restaurant landscaping. Will leaf out in spring.
Tropical evergreen tree/large shrub. Can be grown indoors. Mentioned in garden discussions.
Drought-tolerant perennial with arching grass-like leaves and coral-red flower spikes. Excellent for xeriscaping and no-lawn designs. Hummingbird magnet.

plants.transcript_spelling: Salvia lucantha, Salvia Luca, salvia leucantha
plants.description: Purple and white velvety flower spikes in fall. Major plant for California fall/winter color. Used extensively in landscape designs and no-lawn front yards.

plants.transcript_spelling: salvia gregi, Salvia grei, Salvia greggii
plants.description: Compact perennial sage with flowers in many colors. Highly drought tolerant. Used extensively in California landscapes. 'Mirage Blue' and 'Mirage Purple' cultivars specifically noted for superior performance.
Blue-flowering cultivar of autumn sage. Does better than most salvias according to the designer. Used in front garden remodel.
Purple-flowering cultivar of autumn sage. Companion to 'Mirage Blue' in the front garden remodel.
Dwarf form of Mexican bush sage. More compact growth habit for smaller spaces.

plants.transcript_spelling: Salvia hot lips, Salvia Hot Lips
plants.description: Bicolor red and white flowering salvia. Used in restaurant patio landscaping. Attracts hummingbirds.
Classic Mediterranean perennial herb. Fragrant, drought tolerant. Used in multiple garden designs.

plants.transcript_spelling: Lily of the Nile, Agapanthus, Queen Anne
plants.description: Clump-forming perennial with large spherical blue or white flower clusters. 'Queen Anne' variety mentioned. Common in California landscapes.
Bold architectural perennial with sword-like leaves. Multiple colors and sizes available. Used for dramatic focal points in California gardens.
Cascading perennial with tubular red-orange flowers. 'St. Elmo's Fire' variety mentioned. Excellent for hummingbirds. Arching, fountain-like habit.
Compact flax lily with blue-green strappy foliage and blue berries. Used in front garden remodel. Low maintenance ground-level perennial.

plants.transcript_spelling: silvery sunproof larvia, Laapy, variegated liriope
plants.description: Variegated lilyturf with green and gold-striped foliage. Sun-tolerant variety. Used as edging and ground-level perennial in courtyard plantings.
Grass-like clumping perennial with blue-purple flower spikes. Versatile border and edging plant. Shade tolerant.
Low-growing perennial with fragrant flowers. Used as border and edging plant.
Clumping perennial with garlic-scented foliage and lavender flowers. Drought tolerant. Deer resistant.
Upright succulent perennial with flat flower heads that transition from pink to copper. Fall bloomer.
Succulent perennials in various forms. Low water requirement. Used in rock gardens and borders.
Soft, silvery-furred perennial ground cover. Used in courtyard plantings for texture and color contrast.
Variegated yucca with gold-centered green leaves. Architectural accent plant. Drought tolerant.
California native perennial with large white flowers and yellow centers resembling fried eggs. Dramatic, spreading native plant.
Low-growing perennial with tiny purple flowers. Continuous bloomer in warm weather. Good for borders.
Perennial with clouds of tiny purple and white flowers. Very drought tolerant. Used in no-lawn front yard design.
Tropical-looking perennial with iconic orange and blue crane-like flowers. Used in restaurant patio landscaping.
Peruvian lily. Clumping perennial with colorful lily-like flowers. Long-lasting cut flower. Seen on spring garden tour.
Western native fern with bold, upright fronds. Used in shade gardens. Seen on spring garden tour.
Semi-evergreen fern with coppery new fronds. Used in shade garden renovations.
Delicate deciduous fern for shade gardens. Lacy fronds.
Japanese painted fern with silvery-purple fronds. Shade garden accent.
Compact tropical perennial with deeply lobed leaves. Used in sheltered garden areas for tropical effect.

plants.transcript_spelling: ginger lily, Ginger Lily, ginger fendron
plants.description: Tropical perennial with fragrant flowers and bold foliage. Used in shade gardens, restaurant landscaping, and zoo exhibits. Variegated form provides additional foliage interest.
Colorful edible-flowered perennial/annual. Leaves and flowers are edible. Easy to grow. Self-seeds freely.
Daisy-like perennial herb. Medicinal plant. Self-seeds freely. Used for sandy soil improvement plantings.
Clumping perennial with lily-like flowers. Easy to grow. Used in the low-maintenance garden with Blue Fescue.
Colorful perennial that repels mosquitoes while attracting pollinators. Plant in sun with rich, well-draining soil. Grows back and multiplies each year.
Large-blooming sun-loving perennial. Can be planted in pots or ground. Space 1.5 to 2.5 feet apart depending on variety. Short-lived but spectacular blooms.
Brightly colored perennial. Needs 8-10 hours of sun per day. Known as a pollinator favorite. Also called vervain.
Native perennial with daisy-like flowers. Full sun, several varieties available. Great for beginner gardeners. Native to US, Mexico, and Canada.
Cool-season perennial grown as annual in California. Papery flowers in bright colors. Fall/winter planting.
Cool-season annual with vertical flower spikes. Many colors available. Popular fall/winter annual in California.
Fragrant cool-season annual. Spicy clove-scented flowers. Popular in California winter gardens.
Edible-flowered annual with saffron-colored blooms. Used for anti-inflammatory tinctures. Can top desserts or salads. Takes 6-8 weeks to bloom. Plant in pots or garden beds.
Low-growing fragrant annual. Used as edging and ground cover between pavers. Self-seeds prolifically.
Small white daisy annual. Low growing. Good for borders and edging in cool season.
Popular cool-season annual with face-like flowers in many colors.
Small-flowered relative of pansy. Cool-season annual. Many color options.
Fast-growing drought-tolerant annual. Vibrant colors including magenta, yellow, orange, and cream. Plant spring through late summer.
Bright red or other colored annual salvia. Warm-season bedding plant.
Heat-loving annual with round flowers. Excellent for hot California summers.
Shade-tolerant annual/perennial with waxy flowers. Multiple types available.
Cool-season flowering plant with swept-back petals. Excellent for shade in fall/winter.
Cool-season annual with clusters of bright flowers. Good for winter color.
Cool-season decorative plant with colorful rosettes. Good for fall/winter garden interest.
Popular bedding plant with rounded flower clusters. Multiple colors. Seen on spring garden tour.
Unique colorful annual with plume or brain-shaped flowers. Full sun. Easy to propagate once established. Adds bold interest to gardens.
Fast-growing annual, seed to bloom in 8 weeks. Well-draining soil, water at base not on leaves. Repels mosquitoes and rodents while attracting pollinators.
Annual aster that blooms long after other plants stop. 13 different colors available. Fantastic for pollinators.
Extremely hardy ground cover/shrub. White, lavender, and trailing varieties. Blooms every year. Very drought tolerant once established. Can grow into large shrubs. Multiple colors available.
Low-spreading ground cover form of lantana. Purple or white flowers. Excellent for slopes and banks.
Dense evergreen ground cover. Used in no-lawn front yard designs and as a lawn substitute. Shade tolerant.
Fragrant white-flowering vine/ground cover. Can be used as ground cover or climber. Very popular in California.
Low-spreading juniper ground cover. Extremely drought tolerant. Blue-green foliage.
Low-growing silver-green ground cover. Used between pavers and as lawn substitute. Drought tolerant. Used in no-lawn front yard designs and front garden remodels.
Fragrant low-growing herb used as ground cover. Tiny purple flowers attract bees. Good between stepping stones.
Compact thyme variety used as ground cover. Mixed in with stepping stones and pavers.
Low-growing clover-like ground cover. Can be ornamental or weedy depending on species.
Spectacular flowering vine with colorful bracts. 'Bambino' dwarf variety mentioned. Extremely drought tolerant. Needs full sun and heat. Iconic California vine.
Vigorous deciduous vine with trumpet-shaped orange-red flowers. Attracts hummingbirds. Can be aggressive.
Flowering vine with large showy blooms. Many varieties and colors. Needs roots in shade, top in sun.
Evergreen vine/shrub with orange tubular flowers. Attracts hummingbirds. Can be used as hedge or vine.
Deciduous vine that clings to walls. Brilliant red fall color. Used for covering walls and fences. Discussed for clay soil gardens.

Dramatic deciduous vine with cascading purple flower clusters. Very vigorous. Requires training on strong structure. Featured in multiple videos including training tutorials. Notorious for aggressive growth.
Self-clinging evergreen vine for covering walls. Dense flat growth. Used in zoo landscaping and privacy screen discussions.
Scrambling vine seen on spring garden tour. Purple-tinted foliage and white flowers.

plants.transcript_spelling: blue glow Agave, Agave Blue Glow
plants.description: Dwarf agave with blue-green rosette and red-edged leaves. Used extensively in the designer's low-maintenance garden. Stays manageable size after 7 years. Perfect for small sites.
Larger agave species. Noted as being too big for small garden sites. Blue Glow recommended instead for residential use.
Various succulent species discussed for container gardening. Feed carefully with organic amendments. Popular with homeowners.
Compact white landscape rose. Dwarf sport of the famous Iceberg rose. Used in the front garden remodel. Very disease resistant.
Classic white floribunda rose. One of the most popular landscape roses in California.
Dark red climbing rose. Fragrant. Popular climber for arbors and trellises.
Multi-colored climbing rose with yellow, orange, and red blooms. Eye-catching color display.
Pink climbing rose variety discussed in the climbing roses video.
Yellow climbing rose variety. Good for adding warm color to vertical garden structures.
Thornless bourbon climbing rose with deep pink fragrant flowers. Ideal for areas near pathways due to lack of thorns.
Lavender-colored climbing rose variety. Unique color for a climbing rose.
Orange-toned floribunda rose. Landscape rose with continuous blooming.
Classic long-stemmed roses. Require more maintenance than landscape roses. Discussed in rose society talk.
Low-spreading roses for ground cover use. Less maintenance than hybrid teas.
Rose grafted on a tall standard trunk. Formal accent plant.
Compact blue-gray ornamental grass. Low mounding habit. Used in no-lawn front yard designs and low-maintenance gardens. Drought tolerant.
Graceful cascading ornamental grass. Used in the front garden remodel. Provides soft flowing texture.
Ornamental grass with fuzzy flower plumes. Popular in California landscapes. Can be invasive in some areas.
Variegated evergreen sedge with white-edged leaves. Good shade ground cover. Low maintenance.
Primary warm-season lawn grass for Central Valley. Common and hybrid varieties discussed. Requires proper irrigation, mowing, and soil health. Lawn renovation and overseeding techniques detailed.
Cool-season lawn grass. Shade-tolerant. Used for overseeding and as primary lawn in cooler areas.
Cool-season grass used for overseeding warm-season lawns in fall/winter. Quick germination.
Fine fescue used for shaded areas. Surprisingly looks similar to Bermuda when mixed. Most shade-tolerant lawn grass.
Fine fescue variety for shade areas. Used in lawn overseeding mixes.
Cool-season lawn grass. Part of overseeding mixes. Beautiful but requires more water.
Warm-season lawn grass. Broader blades than Bermuda. More shade tolerant than Bermuda.
Warm-season lawn grass. Dense, carpet-like texture. Moderate water needs.
Running bamboo with dramatic black culms. Grown indoors and outdoors. Can be challenging to contain. Used in the designer's garden and discussed in multiple videos.
Various bamboo species used in zoo Asian exhibit landscaping and privacy screening. Multiple types discussed.
Multi-stemmed fan palm used in restaurant patio landscaping. Shade tolerant. Elegant tropical appearance. Indoor/outdoor versatility.
Various palm species used in zoo landscaping and tropical-themed gardens.
Tropical plant used in zoo exhibits and restaurant landscaping. Large bold foliage provides tropical atmosphere.
Multiple lemon varieties discussed: Lisbon, Eureka (commercial types), Ponderosa (huge fruit), and Meyer (sweeter, cold-hardier hybrid). Dwarf citrus planted in side yards.
Classic eating orange. Multiple varieties for California home orchards.
Orange variety with deep red flesh. Popular specialty citrus for California gardens.
Pink-fleshed navel orange variety. Sweet with berry-like overtones.
Citrus fruit tree for California gardens.
Hybrid between lime and kumquat. Cold-hardier than limes.
Small citrus fruit eaten whole including peel. Grown in containers in the low-maintenance garden. Cold-hardy citrus.
Easy-peel mandarin variety for California home orchards.

plants.transcript_spelling: Golden Nugget Mandarin, Satsuma, Pixie Mandarin, Tango Tangerine, Mandarin Orange
plants.description: Multiple mandarin varieties discussed: Golden Nugget, Satsuma (cold hardy), Pixie, and Tango Tangerine. Popular home orchard citrus.
Large citrus tree. Pink and white varieties mentioned. Prolific producer in California. Seen in multiple garden tours.
Unusual citrus with finger-like segments. Highly fragrant. Used for zest and fragrance rather than juice.
Citrus hybrid of tangerine and grapefruit. Juicy, sweet-tart fruit.
Apple variety that does fantastic in Fresno. One of the best apples for hot Central Valley climates. Planted in backyard orchard.
Apple variety mentioned for home orchard use. Sweet, crisp fruit.
One of the designer's favorite apples. Easy to fit into small yards. Grows in wide range of zones but hard to find. Reminds of Honeycrisp - crisp, tart, and sweet. Ordered online from Michigan.
Small-fruited apple used to make hard cider. Combined with eating apples in edible garden.
Classic yellow freestone peach. Heirloom variety for California orchards.
Old heirloom peach variety. Planted in backyard fruit garden and quirky orchard.
Peach variety planted in backyard orchard. One of the healthiest-looking trees with lots of new growth. No signs of decline or burn.
White-fleshed peach variety in the backyard orchard. Doing very well with new healthy growth. Only one peach on the new tree, which is more appropriate.
Nectarine variety in the backyard orchard. Really good variety but the tree had too many fruit on it for its size.
Heirloom apricot variety. Classic California apricot known for exceptional flavor.
Apricot variety in the backyard orchard. Doing well with new growth at many tips.
Pluot variety (plum-apricot hybrid). Popular in California home orchards.
Pluot variety with mottled skin and red-fleshed interior. Really good variety for home orchards.
Cross between plum and apricot. Planted in backyard orchard. Had problems with army worms. Treated with spinosad organic spray.
Japanese plum variety in the backyard orchard. Some new growth happening with minor chlorosis showing on leaves.

plants.transcript_spelling: Stella, self for Turtle Cherry called Stella
plants.description: Self-fertile sweet cherry that does not need a pollinizer. Lost to overwatering in hot weather in the backyard orchard.
Multiple fig varieties discussed: Violette de Bordeaux (French fig), Black Mission. Small trees good for edible gardens. Designer discussed 'exfoliating' (espalier) technique for fig trees.
Hard, crisp persimmon variety that can be eaten like an apple. Multiple trees planted in the backyard orchard. Owner's favorite. Some fruit burned in heat.
Astringent persimmon variety that gets real soft. Used to make cookies. Not for fresh eating until fully ripe.
Evergreen fruit tree with large tropical-looking leaves. Yellow-orange fruit in spring. Versatile landscape and edible tree.
Major agricultural tree in California's Central Valley. Also grown in home orchards.
Mediterranean fruit/shade tree. Both fruiting and fruitless varieties used extensively in California landscaping.
Grapevine for home vineyard use. Previous homeowner had a small grape vineyard that was removed.
Multiple varieties discussed: Whopper, Sungold, Sun Sugar (cherry types), Crimson Caramello, Beefsteak, Big Zach (3+ lb fruits), and Mortgage Lifter. Detailed growing techniques covered.

plants.transcript_spelling: Onion, Walla Walla, Elsie, Sierra Blanca
plants.description: Winter vegetable garden crop. Varieties include Walla Walla (sweet), Elsie, and Sierra Blanca.
Cool-season crop planted in fall/winter for spring harvest.
Cool-season vegetable. Multiple varieties with different growth habits discussed.
Cool-season vegetable for winter gardens.
Fast-growing cool-season root vegetable.
Cool-season leafy green for winter vegetable gardens.

plants.botanical_name: Brassica rapa / Brassica oleracea x rapa
plants.description: Italian cool-season greens for winter gardens.
Cool-season root and leaf vegetable.
Cool-season vegetable for winter gardens.
Hardy cool-season leafy green.
Cool-season leafy green for winter gardens.
Root vegetable for cool-season gardens.
Spicy cool-season leafy green.
Colorful cool-season leafy green.
Peppery cool-season salad green.
Asian cool-season green for winter gardens.
Root vegetable for spring planting.
Summer vegetable crop mentioned in edible garden context.
Summer fruit/vegetable for warm-season gardens.
Summer melon for warm-season gardens.
Perennial fruit for edible gardens and containers.
Upright rosemary variety. Used as both culinary herb and landscape shrub. Very drought tolerant. Mediterranean plant perfectly suited to California.
Trailing/prostrate rosemary for ground cover use. Used in restaurant patio landscaping. Cascading habit.
Cool-season herb. Bolts quickly in warm weather.
Biennial herb used in cooking. Flat-leaf/Italian variety preferred for flavor.
Annual herb for cool-season and early warm-season gardens.
Perennial Mediterranean herb. Multiple varieties grown. Can be dried for storage. Cut with hedge trimmers when large. Discussed in edible garden tours.
Warm-season annual herb. Essential culinary herb. Fragrant. Discussed in multiple edible garden contexts.
Perennial Mediterranean herb. Culinary and ornamental uses.
Aggressive-growing perennial herb. Needs containment. Multiple varieties available. Can survive winter low temperatures.
Low-growing perennial herb/edging plant. Used for formal herb garden borders.
